text: 262 TH E HISTOR Y book praefect. They found that with one wound he had dispatched himself. His body was burnt without delay. This had been his earnest request, lest his head (b) should fall into the hands of his enemies, and be made a public spectacle. He was borne on the shoulders of the praetorian soldiers to the funeral pile. The men, during the procession, paid all marks of respect to his remains. They printed kisses on his hands, and on the mortal wound, and, in a flood of tears, poured forth their warmest praise. At the funeral pile some of the soldiers put an end to their lives; not from any consciousness of guilt, nor yet im- pelled by fear; but to emulate the ex- ample of their prince, and to show them- selves faithful to the last. At Bedriacum, Placentia, and other camps, numbers fol- lowed the example. A sepulchre (c) was raised to the memory of Otho, but of an ordinary structure, protected by its mean- ness, and therefore likely to last. L. Siich was the end of Otho, in the thirty-seventh year of his age. He was born in the municipal city of Ferentum.
